chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: The goal of this document is to provide a short guide for starting development for the &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; platform: architecture, development environment setup, directory structure and programming tips and conventions.

No, this guide does not present all the mechanisms and functions available to the &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; programmer: it is only a startup guide that will help write the first scripts. Then, there is a lot more to learn by looking at the existing code!

section.title: Skill Requirements
section.para: Even though programming for the &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; platform does not require very advanced skills, existing knowledge in a few technologies will greatly help. More precisely, here are the initial skills that are the most useful:

listitem.para: MySQL and more generally SQL language is used very often when programming for &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME;. With PHP, there is no state saved between successive calls, so all needed data is read from a mySQL database each time a script is executed.
Web application programming: for instance, GET/POST mechanisms, cookies, Apache server, and also rendering languages like HTML, CSS, or Javascript in some cases.

section.title: Programmer References
section.para: Here is a list of useful resources freely available to the programmer:

listitem.para: PHP Manual, available at http://www.php.net/manual/en/: this is an invaluable resource for PHP programmers: function references, comprehensive search and user examples.
MySQL Reference Manual, available at http://dev.mysql.com/doc/mysql/en/index.html: reference manual with SQL syntax, examples and user comments.

&SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; Installation Guide: this guide gives an overview of the system aspects of &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME;: user accounts, file system, RPM packages, SSH, cron jobs, as well as information on &SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; customization: UI themes, site content.

&SYS_PRODUCT_NAME; Administration Guide: this guide details administration tasks, file structure, and tools configuration (MySQL, Apache, CVS, etc.). It is a reference document when it comes to modifying any administrative script.
